headline: Michael Rotondo talks moving out and house hunting

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You're perpetuating fake news on "Watters' World."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, I've got to beat Jeanine and I've got to beat and Jarrett - Gregg Jarrett and Jeanine.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Coming up. One of my favorite interviews of 2018, the 30-year-old evicted from his own parents house. Don't go anywhere.

utterances.speaker: ANNA KOOIMAN, CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Hi there and live from "America's News Headquarters," I am Anna Kooiman. The partial government shutdown is now in its eighth day and still no deal in sight. President Donald Trump and Congressional Democrats remain at odds over funding for a border wall, and this stalemate is likely meaning the shutdown will extend into the New Year. The Senate and the House are not scheduled to hold votes until at least Monday. And new development tonight in the murder of California Police Corporal Ronil Singh shot and killed during a traffic stop. Police have now arrested illegal immigrant, Gustavo Perez Arriaga after a day's long manhunt and now seven others including his girlfriend and brother are in custody for allegedly helping him. We are also learning that the 33-year-old suspect is a member of a violent Mexican American street gang. He said to be arraigned next Wednesday. I am Anna Kooiman, and now back to "Watters" World." For all your news headlines, log on to foxnews.com. Have a great night.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: 2018 gave America record job numbers. With the unemployment rate falling to a 49-year low. It also gave us Michael Rotondo, an unemployed 30-year-old from upstate New York evicted under court order from his own parents' house after living there rent free for eight years. I spoke with Michael about turning his life around and his house hunt.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You went to college, right?

utterances.speaker: MICHAEL ROTONDO, EVICTED FROM PARENTS' HOME
utterances.sentences: Briefly, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Did you graduate from college?

utterances.speaker: ROTONDO
utterances.sentences: Briefly means I didn't graduate. No, I didn't graduate.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So, I thought maybe you matriculated quickly because of your advanced intelligence. What was your major when you were briefly in college?

utterances.speaker: ROTONDO
utterances.sentences: I dropped - I won't say that. I started with engineering and I went to business when that didn't work out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, you dropped out of college?

utterances.speaker: ROTONDO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Why did you drop out of college?

utterances.speaker: ROTONDO
utterances.sentences: My academic habits were very poor, so I really couldn't just integrate into the classes very well.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, so you like engineering and you like business. When you dropped out of college, what happened next?

utterances.speaker: ROTONDO
utterances.sentences: I was - I started in sales. I've held a lot of different sales jobs.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What were you selling?

utterances.speaker: ROTONDO
utterances.sentences: I sold vacuum cleaners. I sold dry-cleaner coupons, I sold - I've done retail, which isn't real professional sales, but I'd done it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So you have had a few jobs, mostly in sales, but does that account for all eight years? You must have been unemployed for a lot of that time, right?

utterances.speaker: ROTONDO
utterances.sentences: No, I drove delivery, which wasn't really a sales job, but I did customer service. That was a significant - that a year and a half, mostly it's been sales.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, were you making any money at these jobs and saving it or were you just spending it on what?

utterances.speaker: ROTONDO
utterances.sentences: I really wasn't saving have much, but I spent it on things that I needed.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Like what?

utterances.speaker: ROTONDO
utterances.sentences: Like food and just conventional things - entertainment, food, gasoline, things like that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What kind of entertainment?

utterances.speaker: ROTONDO
utterances.sentences: Sometimes housing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What kind of entertainment?

utterances.speaker: ROTONDO
utterances.sentences: Well, bars - you go to a bar, that's entertainment, I would say or just leisure time. Sometimes movies, but not often.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, do you vote, Mike?

utterances.speaker: ROTONDO
utterances.sentences: I do vote.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Did you vote for President in 2016?

utterances.speaker: ROTONDO
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Would you like to share who you voted for?

utterances.speaker: ROTONDO
utterances.sentences: I would share that with you. I voted for Gary Johnson.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Gary, somehow that doesn't surprise me. What about Gary Johnson did you like?

utterances.speaker: ROTONDO
utterances.sentences: I like how practical he is with a lot of things. I like how you know, fiscal responsibility is very important for the Libertarian Party. So, you know, I would say that personally...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Hey, Mike, so if fiscal responsibility is something that is important to you, don't you think you might have saved some money and have been fiscally responsible in your personal life.

utterances.speaker: ROTONDO
utterances.sentences: I didn't think of that. That's a good point. I probably should have bought some bonds or something and saved more.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh, maybe.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We hear Mike is still living out on his own. All right, Mike. Moving now from hardly working to working hard -- "Dirty Jobs" star Mike Rowe shared his thoughts on job creation and the American work ethic.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What is your assessment of the American worker in the heartland today?

utterances.speaker: MIKE ROWE, MIKEROWEWORKS, CEO
utterances.sentences: Well, I wish I had something new and radical to say, Jesse. By the way, it's nice to finally meet you. I figured, our paths would cross eventually.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, great to have you on.

utterances.speaker: ROWE
utterances.sentences: Thanks. Yes, we shot in all 50 states, at least a dozen times a piece, and you know, the big lesson on "Dirty Jobs," at least for the people I met, and I'm generalizing, which I hate to do. But there was a sort of a shared awareness, especially in the states that you mentioned, that the people were sort of in on some kind of joke that lot of other Americans really weren't in on. And that's probably an inelegant way to say it, but the bottom line was, there is an absolute disconnect going on. And to your point, a lot of it has to do with how we define meaningful work and whatever it is a good job means in 2018.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Now, when I grew up, my father made me do landscaping and manual labor and you know, hedging and shoveling and mowing and planting and just working with my hands and getting dirty and sweaty. And you know, I hated it at the time, but it really kind of made me become a hard-working person. That I believe has been lost in today's America. Are we ever going to get that back?

utterances.speaker: ROWE
utterances.sentences: Yes, we will, because we have to. Or if we don't, then the consequences are going to be so dire that I can't even imagine what it will look like. You are talking about the kind of jobs that typically get presented as character building.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ROWE
utterances.sentences: You know, the...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And I turned in now to quite a character, didn't I Mike?

utterances.speaker: ROWE
utterances.sentences: ... they're important. You certainly did. Obviously, you are a man who is unafraid to get his hands dirty, but the real issue in my view is not - it's actually an appreciation, right? I mean, it's one thing to affirmatively discourage our kids from learning a useful skill. It's another thing to lose our appreciation for the people who do the kinds of jobs that make civilized life possible for the rest of us. I'm not a shrink, but there is something interesting about the way we grow to resent the very things we wind up depending most upon. And if you look at our workforce and if you look at the jobs that are available right now, 6.3 million available jobs; 75% of them don't require a four-year degree. That's amazing. They require training. They require certification and they require a willingness to do something that most people aren't willing to do. But to affirmatively distance ourselves from the people who are essentially keeping the lights on, you know, it's a bad deal. That's why we have a skills gap, in my view, that's why we have $1.5 trillion of student loans.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: ROWE
utterances.sentences: And that's why we are lending money we don't have to kids who can't pay back to teach them how to do jobs that don't exist anymore.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And you have to start somewhere as a worker whether you're 15, 16, 17, 18 or even in your early 20's. I was a bell hop. I was a valet. I was a bus boy. And those jobs were some of the most of rewarding because I learned that work is just about serving other people. And there's nothing wrong with that no matter at what level. Everybody when they work, they are serving the needs or the interests or the desires of a client or a customer. Now, I was getting my shoes shined the other day here in Manhattan and it was all Latino workers that were shining the shoes, and they were doing a great job. And they are excellent at it. And it's the best shoe shine place in Manhattan, but people say, "Oh, the Latino workers in America, they do the jobs that Americans won't do." Do you find that to be true? Are Americans getting soft and there is no desire to do those types of jobs? Or do you see it in a more economical way?

utterances.speaker: ROWE
utterances.sentences: I think, again, it's kind of dangerous to generalize, but in a very general way, I think what's happened in our country is we have bought into the idea that our happiness is a result of the job we have. So, we make work the enemy. We don't do it on purpose, but when we look at a job like the ones you've just described, we either see them as opportunities or cautionary tales. We've taught our kids that certain types of jobs are the kinds of things you are going to wind up doing if you don't go down the well-worn path of a four-year degree and college debt et cetera et cetera.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right, you're going to be working at McDonalds your whole life if you don't study your school books.

utterances.speaker: ROWE
utterances.sentences: Right, so my foundation has trained about a thousand people in skilled trade jobs that aren't going to be replaced by robots and don't really have the whole immigrant conversation hanging around. I'm talking about plumbers, steam fitters, pipe fitters, welders. These people by and large, many are making six figures. They didn't do it by amassing a huge amount of debt. They did it by looking around seeing where the opportunities were, getting up early, staying late distinguishing themselves and doing all the stuff that we are tacitly telling people is going to make them unhappy. So, I think - look, it's a great conversation because you can't talk about work without talking about job satisfaction.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: ROWE
utterances.sentences: Why are people unhappy to me is the big question. And the reason in my view has absolutely nothing or very little to do with what they do for money.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Up next, toxic masculinity and white privilege collide on "Watter's World."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: From toxic masculinity to the problems and pitfalls of white privilege. Colleges spent this year rewriting labels for millennial minds. Here's what Macia Tupytsin, a professor at the new school told me about male melancholia.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What is toxic masculinity first of all?

utterances.speaker: MASHA TUPITSYN IS A PROFESSOR OF FILM AND GENDER STUDIES
utterances.sentences: I mean, I would say there are different ways to describe it, but the way I refer to it is to think about toxic masculinity as when masculinity has to kind of abuse its power in order to function.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: How would I demonstrate on a day-to-day basis, toxic masculinity?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, I think it's - that's the complicated question, but on a daily basis it would be in your relationships with other people and your relationships with women in the workplace and the way that you relate to your own power in the workplace and your daily life.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Just by being a jerk and offensive and imposing my will on other people?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.sentences: Yes or even negotiating that imposition of will on other people. All right, this idea that you have to kind of stoke my ego or behave a certain way to get ahead.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay so, white masculinity, is now a problem. There is a downfall among white males? How so?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm not saying that there's a downfall. I don't think there is a loss of power although men are always lamenting their loss of power.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: How are we doing that?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.sentences: I think one of the - well this constant idea even someone like President Trump who is always lamenting sort of the good old days or a show like "Madmen" which is always focusing on this kind of loss of supremacy that men once held. So that narrative has been going on and that's ...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And so when Donald Trump says "Make America Great Again," what is he trying to say? That we want to return to the good old days where white men ruled the earth?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.sentences: Yes and still rule the earth, but that is being destabilized and so there is this constant kind of narrative of mourning and loss about what's been lost. But what really needs to happen ...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But couldn't the President just be saying, "I want to go back to the '80s where the economy was roaring and we were doing great?"

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.sentences: And when he was the king.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I mean, couldn't that be what he is saying? Maybe not about ...

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.sentences: But either way, it is self-referential.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: ... white males may be more about let's go back to when America was strong and powerful and the economy was great.

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.sentences: And it was a patriarchy that no one questioned.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, but you don't know when Trump says make America great again, he is talking about wanting to bring back sexism.

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.sentences: So now, we're having a conversation about mind reading as opposed to interpretation.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No, but you brought that up he wanted to go back to those days.

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.sentences: Because these are very old narratives and they don't just refer to national politics. National politics also consists of race and class and gender. It's a kind of packaged deal, right, when you're talking about nation building, you're talking about a lot of other multidimensional things.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, listen, I did not take that from what the President said when he uses that slogan. I guess you're interpreting it...

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.sentences: But I didn't come here to ...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So what do white men need to do in America now? How can we improve in your opinion?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.sentences: Well, to me, the crisis is really about the lack of responsibility and this lack of self-interrogation, right, that's really what - I mean etymologically, the root of crisis means this point at which change must come.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But do you mean ...

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.sentences: So the either the change can come or it won't, but what had needs to happen is that when men start doing some the work and interrogation around masculinity as opposed all of these other sort of special interest groups who study ...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, so let's just study it step-by-step. I'm a man, I'm a white man. What do I need to ask myself or what do I need to address internally about my white male?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.sentences: Well, I would say two things to start with, so one is what kind of privileges have I inherited because of my whiteness and my straight masculinity, let's say?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: White privilege.

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.sentences: White privilege but it also has to do masculinity, so I would ask - and we all have to ask that question. What privileges do we come into the world with and do we abuse those privileges? The second question...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, you want white men - just take a step back, you want white men to recognize that they have certain advantages by being born a white straight man?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.sentences: Yes, that they use.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And use and I, as a white, straight male should be more conscious of my privileges when I go walk around in everyday society?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.sentences: You should be, but most likely you won't be because you don't have to.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I walk into a bar as a straight white male, am I being too confident when I walk into the bar? Or should I go in a more humble way?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.sentences: But then I do not how you are when you walk into a bar. I just know that men can behave a certain way in public settings and in bars that is different from women. I mean, this is the case for everyone, right? There are codes that we are all following. Even if we just go to work and we don't behave a certain way, we get fired.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Like I can be loud and obnoxious and I can buy people drinks ...

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.sentences: And sexually aggressive.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: ... and I could flirt with people, is that what you're saying?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And women can't do that?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.sentences: Well, they might do it, but they pay a different price for it. Even just on the level of you might not be seen as someone desperate if you're a single man that walks into a bar, whereas if a woman walks into a bar and she is single, that is perceived as a very different kind of social gesture.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And then lastly, what was the other question I am supposed to ask myself as a straight white male?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.sentences: Well, you've interrupted me so many times, and now, I can't remember.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I guess that's probably my toxic masculinity.

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.sentences: Probably.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Christianity also coming under fire this year, George Washington University, holding a seminar bashing the religion for giving American Christians what it views as an unfair privilege. I spoke to Warren Blumenfield, an adjunct professor at University of Massachusetts at Amherst, about the controversy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You say there is Christian privilege here. Is there not Christian privilege in the Middle East, is there?

utterances.speaker: WARREN BLUMENFELD, ADJUNCT PROFESSOR, UNIVERSITY OF MASSACHUSETTS AT AMHERST
utterances.sentences: We are talking about the United States right now, but there is Christian privilege around the world in many ways, but I would like to correct you. It's not bashing Christianity, it's raising issues of the ways in which Christians automatically have this unearned privilege just by being Christian in the United States context in a western ...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And what would that privilege be?

utterances.speaker: BLUMENFELD
utterances.sentences: There is a lot of ways that privilege manifests itself. In the 1840s, a theorist went around the United States and he wrote this great book called "Democracy In America," Alexis de Tocqueville and he discovered that there is this paradox in some ways, that the United States positioned itself around the world as this country which promoted itself as a religious pluralism. But he found that the Christian churches had so much power, that in many ways, it could be considered to be the first example of the first institution of politics because it had so much power and so much weight on politics in the United States.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, I don't think any more that the Christian church has that type of power. I mean, it's a pretty religiously pluralistic nation and there is...

utterances.speaker: BLUMENFELD
utterances.sentences: And that's one of the myths that we were ...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: ... and now, you can't have the Ten Commandments at the courthouse or you know, if you are a Christian and you want to say "Merry Christmas" in public school, they yell at you. You can't have a Christmas tree, they call it a Holiday tree. Is that privilege?

utterances.speaker: BLUMENFELD
utterances.sentences: We are talking about religious pluralism. The school year is founded on the Christian calendar. If I want to take a day off to go to - do you even know what the holiest day is on the Jewish calendar is?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No, tell me.

utterances.speaker: BLUMENFELD
utterances.sentences: And that's a form of Christian privilege. You don't have to know other religions of when our holidays are. It's Yom Kippur, which is the Day of Atonement. And it usually comes ...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, so I have the privilege of not knowing what your most devout holiday is? That's a privilege to not know something?

utterances.speaker: BLUMENFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. You don't have to know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I would think that that would be the opposite. I feel bad that I don't know. I mean, you know, listen there's not a lot of Jewish Americans in the country compared to Christian Americans. I don't know the most of devout Muslim holiday either.

utterances.speaker: BLUMENFELD
utterances.sentences: Of course. And again, minoritized people have to know of the holidays of Christians for our own survival because it's just self-promoted.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, let's solve this then because I don't want Christian privilege. I just want to be open and I want to know everything about every other person and I don't want to feel privileged. What can I do as a Christian to make myself feel less privileged?

utterances.speaker: BLUMENFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm not asking you to make yourself less privileged. I am asking you to share your privilege, like as a white man, I don't want to lose my white privilege. I don't want to walk into a store and be tailed, racially profiled. I am not saying I want to lose that. But I am working as a white person so that I share my privilege so that nobody is racially profiled.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Up next. I tried goat yoga. Yes, yoga with goats. I can't believe I'm showing you guys this. Stick around.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Just put your hand right here on the horse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Nice deep breath in.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's good. That's good. No teeth, right. You said it had no teeth.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: No teeth. No teeth. You can do it. You can do it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, okay. I got it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's no secret that I am not a big animal lover, but sometimes, you just need to lean in. I did exactly that when Terin Alogenegro (ph) Christine Browak and their four-legged friends stopped by to show me a few moves of the newest trends taking the country by storm, goat yoga.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: So I want you to bring your big toes together to touch. We are going to start in a mountain pose, so bring your arms down to your side, palms face forward, fingertips spread wide and really feel grounded here. SO you really want to feel rooted down into the ground.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I feel very grounded right now.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Good, so we want to start with our breath, so take a deep inhale through your nose.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I smell goat.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: And then open your mouth and just sigh in out all out. One more time, take a nice deep inhale and sigh it all out. On your next inhale, just reach the arms up overhead and on an exhale let's fold all the way down, so we're coming to a forward fold.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That wasn't me.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Once you're there, we're going to plan our palms down to the mat, step back to a plank pose.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh gosh.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: So this is where you get that six-pack. You want to bring your hips up even with shoulders here, so bring them up a little bit.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Higher? Okay.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Take a breath here, inhale. On your next exhale, we're going to lower the belly all the way down to the mat, nice and slow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Once you're there, you can untuck your toes. We're going to come to cobra, so press through the palms and start to straighten the elbows, press the chest forward, nice back bends here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What are the goats supposed to be doing right now?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I think they are making you happy, right? Relax. Relax your shoulders, take a breath, exhale slowly, lower the heart all the way back down.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Is this goat wearing a diaper?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: And we're going to come to a child's pose, so you want to sync your hips back to your heels here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I know that pose. Hold on.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: So you could walk your fingertips forward, so you can walk your fingertips forward, let your forehead rest on the mat just to make sure there is no food or maybe some poop there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh, I'm good.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: And then start to make your way to a table top position, so come to all fours, shoulders over wrists, hips over knees and we are going to go through a few rounds of cow cat or maybe goat cap or whatever you want to call it today.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: When are we going to do downward goat?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We'll do that actually next, so come back to a neutral spine here, tuck the toes, and we're going to press back to downward facing dog, but for today, it will downward facing goat.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh that hurts.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Something about these animals got me hooked, because I got a dog this year. I can't believe I did. His name is Rookie Watters, and he is absolutely adorable. Like me. Up next, "Last Call."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Time now for "Last Call." It ceases to amaze how little the average American knows about our country. I hit the streets for a lightning round on current events and here's the best or the worst.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Who is the Vice President?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I don't know and I really don't care.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Oh my god.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Name one state that borders Canada.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Ohio.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: New York City.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Massachusetts.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: North Carolina.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Not California, right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What does the CIA stand for?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: That I do not know.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I am going to guess like Constitution, but I am going to guess that that's wrong.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's wrong. Who was the first person to set foot on the moon?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: David Wright.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That was the baseball player.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: The moon is dumb, there is not even a Walmart there. Who cares?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's all for this year. Have a happy 2019, I know, I will. "Justice with Judge Jeanine" is next, and remember, I'm Watters and this is my world.
